title: 把 (bǎ) - The 'ba' construction
short_explanation: Used to shift the object to before the verb in a sentence.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese character '把 (bǎ)' is used in a specific grammatical construction that allows the object to be stated before the verb. In English, this is equivalent to changing the sentence structure to 'Subject + 把 + Object + Verb'. It makes the sentence more specific about how the verb affects the object.
formation: Subject + 把 + Object + Verb + Result

examples.pinyin: Wǒ bǎ tāng hē wán le.
examples.en: I finished drinking the soup.

title: 被 (bèi) - Passive marker
short_explanation: Used to indicate passive voice in a sentence.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese particle '被 (bèi)' is used to form passive sentences. In a passive sentence, the object of an action becomes the subject of the sentence. The actual subject performing the action can be omitted if the context makes it clear. The particle '被' is used to mark the agent of the action when it is mentioned in the sentence.
formation: Subject + 被 + Agent + Verb + Object

examples.cn: 这本书被我弟弟借走了。
examples.pinyin: Zhè běn shū bèi wǒ dìdì jiè zǒu le.
examples.en: This book was borrowed by my younger brother.

title: 一下 (yīxià) - A short or quick action; momentarily
short_explanation: Used to denote a brief or quick action.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese phrase '一下 (yīxià)' is used directly after a verb, indicating that the action lasts for a short, brief or quick moment. It gives the expression of trying out or giving something a shot. This term makes the command or request sound softer and more gentle.

title: 再说 (zàishuō) - Moreover, furthermore
short_explanation: Used to add additional information or arguments to a point.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese phrase '再说 (zàishuō)' is used when you want to add more information or arguments to support your point or opinion. It is equivalent to saying 'moreover' or 'furthermore' in English. This phrase is typically used when you are stating reasons, expressing opinions, or describing situations to add weight to your statements.
formation: Reason, opinion, or situation + 再说 + Additional information or argument

examples.cn: 我不想去那个派对，我太累了，再说我明天还有个大考试。

title: 最 (zuì) - Most, -est (superlative marker)
short_explanation: Used to express the highest degree or the utmost extent of something.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese character '最(zuì)' is a superlative marker. When used in a sentence, it denotes the highest level, degree, or the utmost point of something. In essence, it is similar to using 'most' or the suffix '-est' in English to illustrate a superlative. '最' can be used with both adjectives and verbs.
formation: 最 + Adjective / Verb

examples.cn: 这就是我见过最高的山。

title: 比如 (bǐrú) - For example
short_explanation: Used to introduce examples as a way to illustrate a point.
long_explanation: '比如 (bǐrú)' is used in Mandarin Chinese to introduce an example or examples in order to clarify or explain the previous statement or point. It has the same function as the English 'for example', and is frequently used to make sentences clearer or more specific.
formation: Topic + Statement + 比如 + Example

title: 可是 (kěshì) - But, however
short_explanation: Used for expressing concession or contrast.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese phrase '可是 (kěshì)' serves the purpose of presenting a contrast or contradiction between two thoughts or ideas. It essentially functions in a similar manner to the English conjunctions 'but' and 'however'. Generally, the word ‘可是’ is used in the second half of a sentence to juxtapose two conflicting or contrasting ideas.
formation: Sentence 1，可是 + Sentence 2

title: 已经 (yǐjīng) - Already
short_explanation: Used to describe an action that has happened or a state that already exists.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese word '已经 (yǐjīng)' is used to express that an action or state has already occurred or exists. It is the equivalent of the English word 'already'. title: 还 (hái) - Still, yet; in addition
short_explanation: Expresses the continuity of an action or a state, or it implies that there is more or additional.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese term '还 (hái)' carries two main implications based on context. First, it can be used to indicate a continuing action or state, similar to 'still' or 'yet' in English. Secondly, it can indicate the addition of something or someone else to what has already been mentioned, comparable to the English term 'in addition'.
formation: 1. Subject + 还 + Verb + Object (continuity), 2. Subject + 还 + Verb + 其他的 + Object (addition)

title: 才 (cái) - Only just, not until
short_explanation: Used to emphasize that something happened later than expected or desired.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese term '才 (cái)' is a commonly used expression indicating that an action or event has occurred later than one would typically expect or want. It implies a sense of lateness or delay and is equivalent to the English expressions 'only just' or 'not until'. It is usually used in the context of activities that have completed, actions that were accomplished later than desired, or conditions that were not met until a particular requirement was fulfilled.

title: 就 (jiù) - Then, precisely, just
short_explanation: Used to express that something happened earlier than expected, or exactly as stated, and to highlight a specific item or action.
long_explanation: 就 (jiù) is a versatile word in Mandarin Chinese, often translated as 'then', 'precisely', or 'just' in English. It is used to indicate that something happens earlier than expected, or in a more exact or extreme manner than expected. It can also be used to highlight a specific item or action or to link cause and effect.
formation: Subject + 就 + Verb + Rest of the sentence

title: 一直 (yīzhí) - Continuously, all along
short_explanation: Used to denote that an action or state continues unbroken or without interruption.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese word '一直 (yīzhí)' is used to suggest an unbroken sequence or a continual action or state. It can be understood in English as 'continuously', 'all along', 'straight' or 'all the way'. It is used to express something has been happening from a certain point of time and is still happening, or will continue happening.
formation: Subject + Time + 一直 + Verb

examples.cn: 他一直在努力提高他的汉语水平，以便可以顺利通过HSK种语考试。

examples.en: He has been continuously striving to improve his Chinese level so that he can pass the HSK Chinese language test smoothly.

examples.cn: 我一直从北京走到上海，整个旅途中我都在欣赏中国美丽的风景。

examples.en: I traveled all the way from Beijing to Shanghai, admiring the beautiful scenery of China throughout the journey.

examples.cn: 我妹妹一直哭，因为她的玩具熊丢失了。

title: 一般 (yībān) - Generally, normally
short_explanation: Used to represent a general or usual situation.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese term '一般 (yībān)' translates to 'generally' or 'normally' in English and is used to convey a usual, typical, or general situation or state of affairs. It's a simple way to suggest that something tends to be a certain way most of the time. In a sentence, you can use it before or after the verb, but it is more common to use it before the verb.
formation: Subject + 一般 + Verb + Object

examples.cn: 一般来说，你每天都会去跑步吗？是的，我一般每天早上去跑步。

examples.cn: 我一般在周末才看电影。

examples.cn: 他在读书的时候一般不喜欢被打扰。

examples.en: He generally doesn't like to be disturbed when he is reading.

examples.cn: 她一般都很准时，但今天她迟到了。

title: 真的 (zhēnde) - Really, truly
short_explanation: Used to emphasize the truth or sincerity of a statement or action.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese phrase '真的 (zhēnde)' is used to accentuate the factuality or genuineness of a particular statement or action. It translates to 'really' or 'truly' in English and is used to verify or affirm a matter. It is frequently used in conversations to show surprise or to strongly confirm something.
formation: Subject + Verb/Adjective + 真的 + Rest of the sentence

examples.cn: 她真的会说五种不同的语言，同意真的令人印象深刻。

examples.en: She really can speak five different languages, it's truly impressive.

examples.en: I really love this city's culture and history, it makes me want to explore places like this more.

examples.cn: 昨天的音乐会真的是太棒了，我真的过得很愉快。

examples.cn: 他真的完成了马拉松比赛，这真的是一个伟大的成就。

title: 可能 (kěnéng) - Maybe, possibly
short_explanation: Used to express the possibility or likelihood of a certain event or situation.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese word '可能 (kěnéng)' is used to indicate that something might or might not happen or be true. It signifies the uncertainty or possibility related to a certain event, action, or condition. It is equivalent to 'maybe', 'possibility', or 'might' in English. You can use '可能' at the beginning of a sentence or right before the verb or adjective.
formation: 可能 + Sentence / Subject + 可能 + Verb + Object

examples.cn: 明天可能会下雨，所以我们要带雨伞。
examples.pinyin: Míngtiān kěnéng huì xià yǔ, suǒyǐ wǒmen yào dài yǔsǎn.
examples.en: It might rain tomorrow, so we need to take umbrellas.

examples.en: He might know we're talking about him, because he's looking at us.

examples.cn: 我想她可能在等她的朋友。

title: 一起 (yīqǐ) - Together
short_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese word '一起 (yīqǐ)' indicates a joint action or activity done by two or more individuals.
long_explanation: In Mandarin Chinese, '一起 (yīqǐ)' is commonly used to imply actions or activities that are done together by two or more people. Translatable to 'together' in English, the term signifies collaboration, association, or companionship in a particular activity. '一起 (yīqǐ)' usually appears after the subject and before the verb in a sentence.
formation: Subject + 一起 + Verb + Object

examples.cn: 我们一起去图书馆看书，我们可以互相帮助理解难的部分。

examples.en: Let's go to the library to read together, we can help each other understand the difficult parts.

examples.en: What preparations are you and your friends making together for the outdoor activity? We have prepared a lot of food and drinks together.

title: 根据 (gēnjù) - According to, based on

long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese phrase '根据 (gēnjù)' is used to introduce the basis or ground on which a claim, choice, action, or conclusion is drawn. It is equivalent to saying 'according to' or 'based on' in English. This phrase is often used in formal or academic contexts to refer to evidence, laws, rules, and so forth.
formation: 根据 + Source/Information + Rest of the sentence

examples.en: According to the weather forecast, it will rain tomorrow.

examples.en: According to the rules, students are not allowed to bring mobile phones into the classroom.

title: 除非 (chúfēi) - Unless
short_explanation: Used to express a condition in which something will happen or is possible.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese phrase '除非 (chúfēi)' is used to present a prerequisite condition for a certain outcome to happen. It is equivalent to saying 'unless' in English. The situation or condition being mentioned is often necessary or crucial for the rest of the sentence to be true, or for a certain event to occur.
formation: 除非 + Condition, 否则/不然 + Result

title: 以前 (yǐqián) - Before, previously

formation: Subject + 以前 + Verb + Object

examples.cn: 以前我每天都去跑步，但现在我太忙了。

title: 刚刚 (gānggāng) - Just now/recently
short_explanation: Used to refer to recent past events or actions.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese phrase '刚刚 (gānggāng)' is used to indicate that an event or action happened recently or just now. title: 因为…所以… (yīnwèi… suǒyǐ…) - Because... so...
short_explanation: Used to explain a cause-effect relationship.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese expression '因为…所以…' is a correlating conjunction used to express a cause-effect relationship. The clause after '因为' indicates the reason or cause and the clause after '所以' indicates the result or effect. It is equivalent to 'because... so...' in English.

title: 突然 (tūrán) - Suddenly

long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese adverb '突然 (tūrán)' is used to convey a sense of suddenness or unexpectedness. long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese term '又 (yòu)' is utilized to denote that a certain action or circumstance has happened again. short_explanation: Used to give negative commands or to tell someone not to do something.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese word '别 (bié)' is an imperative negative command used to instruct or advise someone not to carry out a specific action. title: 先...然后 (xiān... ránhòu) - First...then...
short_explanation: Used to express the chronological order of events.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese phrase '先...然后 (xiān... ránhòu)' is used to describe the logical sequence of actions or situations. short_explanation: Used to limit the quantity or degree of something.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese word '只 (zhǐ)' is used to express limitation in quantity or degree. In English, it is equivalent to 'only'. '只' has the function to limit and is generally placed before the verb or the numeral-measure word phrase, to stress the quantity or degree of something.

title: 比如说 (bǐrú shuō) - For instance, such as

long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese term '比如说 (bǐrú shuō)' is used to give an example or a series of examples. This term is used in polite suggestions or advice, often signifying a better or more suitable choice given a certain context or scenario.

title: 的话 (de huà) - Used at the end of a conditional clause
short_explanation: Used to express a condition or hypothetical situation.
long_explanation: In Mandarin Chinese, '的话 (de huà)' is a conjunction used to indicate a conditional or hypothetical situation. It can be translated to 'if' in English. When '的话' is used, it usually comes at the end of the clause that represents the condition. Therefore, the structure of the sentence typically is 'Condition + 的话, Outcome'.
formation: Condition + 的话, Outcome

examples.cn: 如果你不喜欢这部电影的话，我们可以换一部看。
examples.pinyin: Rúguǒ nǐ bù xǐhuān zhè bù diànyǐng de huà, wǒmen kěyǐ huàn yī bù kàn.
examples.en: If you don't like this movie, we can switch to another one.

title: 再 (zài) - Again; then (in future actions)
short_explanation: Used to indicate a future action or event that's going to take place again or after something else.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese word '再 (zài)' is used to express the concept of doing something 'again' or 'another time'. It can also be used to denote the sequence of future actions, similar to the English 'then'. The action or event mentioned with '再' hasn't happened yet at the moment of speaking.
formation: Subject + Verb + 再 + Verb

title: 除了...都 (chúle...dōu) - Except for..., all...
short_explanation: This phrase is used to express 'except for' or 'other than'.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese phrase '除了...都 (chúle...dōu)' is used to indicate the exclusion of a specific item, person, or situation from a general statement. Essentially, it signifies that all others (indicated by '都') follow this statement except for the mentioned exception ('除了'). Note that sometimes '都' can be omitted, especially when the meaning is clear.

title: 对 (duì) - Correct, right; towards
short_explanation: A frequently used word in Mandarin meaning 'correct', 'right', or 'towards', often used to confirm accuracy or indicate direction.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese term '对 (duì)' has multiple uses and meanings. Firstly, it is used as an adjective to indicate that something is 'correct' or 'right'. In this sense, it's often used in response to a question or statement to confirm the correctness or accuracy of the information. Secondly, '对' can be used as a preposition to mean 'towards' or 'to' indicating a direction or position relative to the speaker or context.

short_explanation: Used to express possibility or uncertainty.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese word '可能 (kěnéng)' is used to express the possibility or uncertainty of an event or situation. It is equivalent to 'maybe' or 'possibly' in English. This word can be used in making assumptions, predictions or in expressing someone's capacity to do something.

title: 从来 (cónglái) - Always/Never
short_explanation: Used to indicate something that constantly happens or a state that has never occurred.
long_explanation: In Mandarin Chinese, '从来 (cónglái)' is a temporal adverb used to express that a certain condition or habit has always been the case or that something has never happened before when combined with a negation (不 or 没). It is equivalent to 'always' or 'never' in English. When using '从来' to mean 'never', '没' or '不' usually follows '从来'.

title: 后来 (hòulái) - Later on, afterwards
short_explanation: Used to express a sequence of events, particularly when describing something that happened after some other actions.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese adverb '后来 (hòulái)' is used to indicate a later or subsequent event in a sequence of events. It can be closely translated to 'later on' or 'afterwards' in English. This adverb usually follows a narrative or description of a previous event, facilitating a chronological understanding of the story or occurrence.
formation: Previous Event + 后来 + Following Event

examples.cn: 我小时候住在北京，后来搬到了上海。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ xiǎo shíhou zhù zài Běijīng, hòulái bān dào le Shànghǎi.
examples.en: When I was a child, I lived in Beijing, but later I moved to Shanghai.

examples.en: He initially worked in the finance department, but was later promoted to the position of general manager.

title: 突然 (tūrán) - Suddenly, unexpectedly
short_explanation: Used to express sudden or unexpected actions or changes.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese term '突然 (tūrán)' is utilized to convey the suddenness or unexpectedness of an event, action or situation. It's analogous to the English words 'suddenly' or 'unexpectedly'. It emphasizes the event occurred without any prior indication or warning. It can also be used to describe a swift, drastic change.
formation: Subject + 突然 + Verb + Object.

examples.pinyin: Wǒ zhèngzài zǒu zài jiē shàng, tūrán kāishǐ xià dàyǔ.

title: 对了 (duìle) - By the way; oh right
short_explanation: '对了' is used to introduce a new topic or to suddenly recall something of importance.
long_explanation: The Chinese phrase '对了 (duìle)' closely aligns with the English expressions 'By the way' or 'Oh right', and is used to shift the conversation to a new topic, or to bring up a pertinent point that one almost forgot to mention. It can stand alone or be part of a sentence, and often injects an element of surprise to the conversation, indicating a quick change in the speaker’s train of thought.
formation: 对了 + Rest of the sentence

examples.cn: 对了，我昨天看到了你的老朋友。
examples.pinyin: Duìle, wǒ zuótiān kàn dào le nǐ de lǎo péngyǒu.
examples.en: By the way, I saw your old friend yesterday.

title: 最近 (zuìjìn) - Recently
short_explanation: Used to describe a recent or the most recent period of time.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese term '最近 (zuìjìn)' is commonly used to refer to the recent or the most recent period or point in time. It is somewhat equivalent to the English term 'recently' or 'lately'. The term '最近 (zuìjìn)' can be used to express past events that happened in the near past, as well as forthcoming events in the near future.
formation: 最近 + Verb/Adjective/Time

examples.cn: 我最近很忙，没时间陪你。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ zuìjìn hěn máng, méi shíjiān péi nǐ.
examples.en: I have been very busy recently, no time to be with you.

title: 已经 (yǐjīng) - Already
short_explanation: Used to indicate that an action has already happened.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese word '已经 (yǐjīng)' is used to signify that an action or event has already taken place. It is often used in conjunction with the '了 (le)' particle at the end of the sentence to reinforce the completed aspect of the verb. It highlights that the action is not just completed, but completed before the expected time.
formation: Subject + 已经 + Verb + 了 + Rest of the sentence

examples.cn: 我已经吃过早饭了，所以现在我不饿。

title: 一直 (yīzhí) - Continuously, always, all the way
short_explanation: Used to describe continual, unbroken actions or situations over a certain period of time.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese adverb '一直 (yīzhí)' can be translated as 'continuously', 'always', or 'all the way'. It expresses an action or state that continues unbrokenly over a certain period of time or up to a certain point. It is equivalent to 'keep doing something' or 'all the way' in English.
formation: Subject + 一直 + Verb + Rest of the sentence

examples.en: She has been busy preparing for the exam all this time because she wants to pass the HSK exam.

examples.cn: 他一直在看电影，直到深夜还没有睡觉。

title: 除了...以外 (chúle...yǐwài) - Apart from.../Except for...

long_explanation: The phrase '除了...以外 (chúle...yǐwài)' in Mandarin Chinese is used when you want to express the concept of 'except for' or 'aside from'. The structure helps to emphasize that besides what is mentioned, there are also other factors or elements. This can be used with both nouns and verbs.
formation: 除了 + Noun/Verb Phrase + 以外, Sentence

title: 所以 (suǒyǐ) - So, therefore
short_explanation: Used to express cause and effect or conclude something.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese term '所以 (suǒyǐ)' is used to conclude or express the effect of a cause. It is equivalent to saying 'so' or 'therefore' in English. It is often used in response to an explanation or to describe the result of a situation after explaining the reasons.
formation: Cause + ， + 所以 + Effect

title: 为了 (wèile) - For, in order to, for the sake of

formation: 为了 + Purpose/Reason + Subject + Verb + Object

title: 虽然 (suīrán) - Although, though
short_explanation: Used to express contrast or contradiction between two clauses.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese phrase '虽然 (suīrán)' is used to introduce a clause which contains the information that is being contrasted with or contradicted by another clause. It is equivalent to the English conjunctions 'although' or 'though'. The structure typically followed by 虽然 is '虽然...但是...', where '...但是...' contains the contrasting or contradicting information.

The second part '但是 (dànshì)', introduces a contrast or contradiction to the first statement.

title: 否则 (fǒuzé) - Otherwise, or else
short_explanation: Used to present a negative consequence if a certain condition is not met.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese conjunction '否则 (fǒuzé)' is used to present an undesirable outcome or a negative situation, which might occur if a particular condition is not fulfilled or a required action is not taken. It is similar to 'otherwise' or 'or else' in English. It creates a sense of warning and suggests the need to meet certain conditions to escape the negative consequence.
formation: Clause 1 + 否则 + Clause 2

examples.pinyin: Nǐ xūyào měitiān ànshí fúyòng zhèxiē yào, fǒuzé nǐ de jiànkāng huì shòudào yǐngxiǎng.
examples.en: You need to take these medicines punctually every day, otherwise your health will be affected.

examples.cn: 我们要尽早离开，否则我们会错过火车。

long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese word '而 (ér)' is a conjunction used to connect clauses or sentences. It is similar to 'and', 'but', or 'yet' in English. This word can be used to express contrast between two ideas, or continuation of an idea, depending on the context.
formation: Clause 1 + 而 + Clause 2

title: 随便 (suíbiàn) - Casual, careless; as one wishes
short_explanation: This phrase is used to express doing something casually, in a random manner, or as one likes.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese term '随便 (suíbiàn)' is used when someone does something casually or does as they wish without paying much attention. It is commonly used to express an indifference, or when giving someone the freedom to choose or act as they please. It's similar in use to 'whatever' or 'any' in English.

title: 即使 (jíshǐ) - Even if, even though
short_explanation: Used to state a condition and simultaneously emphasize the hypothetical circumstances that will follow.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese phrase '即使 (jíshǐ)' is used to indicate a hypothetical situation and emphasize that the results will remain the same despite this hypothetical situation. It's equivalent to using 'even if' or 'even though' in English. This conjunction is usually followed by '也 (yě)' in the secondary clause.
formation: 即使 + Condition, Subject + 也 + Verb/Adjective + Rest of the sentence.

examples.cn: 即使下雨，我们也要去公园看音乐会。

long_explanation: '当然 (dāngrán)' is a common word in Mandarin Chinese that is used to express a strong affirmation or agreement. This can be used to answer a question, express one's own opinion, or affirm someone else's statement. It conveys a sense of certainty and can often give emphasis in a conversation. By using '当然', you can easily convey your agreement with someone else's opinion or reassure others of a certain fact.
